column11: The Demodara railway loop is a marvel of engineering, snaking its way through the lush hills of Ella. This unique loop, where the train track winds beneath itself, offers breathtaking views of tea plantations, valleys, and the railway line itself. The mechanism of the Demodara loop is considered to be an engineering marvel from the British colonial era. An arc of the loop can be visualized from a several spots closer to the Demodara Railway Station. However, the whole course of the loop and the mechanism is not discernible with these spots. It is recommended that you check the train schedule from the Ella Railway Station and reach the Demodara station 45mins prior to the scheduled train time. The experienced local trishaw drivers would take you to a higher elevation mount located some 8km away from where you can get a proper view of the whole mechanism, a range of mountains including little Adams Peak. The return trip to this spot from the Demodara station on trishaw costed three of us LKR 1,500 only.

My wife, our grandson Ryan and I parked our car at Ella railway station, on 23rd July 2019, and hired a tuk-tuk that took us first to the "Nine Arch Bridge" and then to Demodera railway station.  We went there to see the famous 'spiral loop' at Demodera.  The train coming from the up-country enters the tunnel located right under the station.  Though at different levels, the tunnel is almost perpendicular to the station.  It then traverses around the adjoining hill in an upward spiral coming up to the station and proceeds towards Ella.  We observed the train passing along, after it emanated from the tunnel.  When it arrived at the station we got in and travelled down to Ella. The legend has it that, during railway construction, engineers had been perplexed to find a means of bridging the considerable vertical level difference between two adjoining hills. A person tying his turban around his head is said to have implanted the idea of the loop to bridge this gap by circumscribing the hill. Demodera loop is 1049 feet feet long at a gradient of 1 in 44, the maximum allowable in Sri Lanka Railway construction. The quaint Demodera railway station reminded me of the time when I travelled to school by train.  The trains in this section of the railway still rely on exchanging tablets on arrival.  The ticket holding cupboard and even the appearance of the clock in the station master's room have remained unchanged from the 1950s. On the way back from Ella we passed over the 'Nine Arch Bridge', where there were many tourists waiting to see it pass by.

The train, between Badulla and Ella takes a spiral loop, going through a tunnel underneath the Demodara railway station to maintain the maximum allowed gradient of 1:44. You need an experienced driver, I recommend DAMMIKA, who keeps his safari jeep near Demodara station. Price reasonable and well worth. You can see the entire loop, starting from the black bridge. Demodara loop, also known as the the spiral railway is recognised as one of the most fascinating civil engineering marvels in Sri Lanka. It is definitely one of the perfect spots for stunning pictures. The rail line passes under itself, going around the loop and emerging from a tunnel, which runs directly beneath the Demodara railway station. The rail loop is approximately 900 metres long and the tunnel is 320 metres in length. It is considered the only loop in the world with a railway station situated exactly over a tunnel at spiral loop

You need to go to the front of the cabin to take pictures, right side in that direction has the better views. but you can see mountains and vast tea plantations from all seats.

Demodara, on the Badulla Railway line, is the only place in Sri Lanka where the railway line does a complete loop, before exiting through a tunnel onto the Demodara railway bridge, when proceeding towards Badulla. If you prefer to travel along the loop, note that when proceeding towards Badulla, the loop is just AFTER the Demodara station. I prefer to walk the entire loop. For this, the best way is to get down at Demodara railway station, view the historical details of the loop and its construction, displayed at the station, and then walk along the railway line.  Be sure to ascertain the train times beforehand, since you will need to walk through a tunnel. The railway is single-line, and this obviously means that when a train goes in one direction, another cannot come from the opposite direction for some time. Ideal for train-spotting.

I took the train from Ella station to Demodara for 10LKR. Train was an hour late... however! Super fun train ride as I nabbed a seat in the doorway. All the locals scream as they go through the two tunnels. Fun to watch the train do the loop at Demodara. I then took a tuktuk to 9 arch bridge, you could do this or walk. Great fun!

Demodara loop was engineered to achieve the required climb/descend of the railway. The railway loops and goes under itself. You can view this from the Demodara Railway station (walk few meters from the platform). What you see is the railway going under where you're standing on. You actually can't see the whole loop together unless viewed from a helicopter. We did this excursion by boarding the Colombo to Badulla "Podi Menike" train at Diyatalawa Station at 3:30pm (as we were staying at Diyatalawa). You can board this train at Ella as well. If you're going directly to Demodara station to view this, please check train times to see at what times trains arrive/depart as this is not a line with a lot of trains. We got off at Demodara, and walked few meters where you can see the Railway underneath where it goes underneatch after the negotiating the loop. You see the same train that you arrived going underneath. After this, we walked down to the railway (easy walk downhill), and walked along to the bridge nearby. Then we walked along the Railway tunnel (this is the tunnerl under the Demodara station) and climbed up from the other side of the hill (somewhat steep but short climb). Tips: If you're coming here on board a Train, the Nine Arches Bridge is between Ella and Demodara Stations. Get on board a Badulla bound train at Ella (or prior to Ella) and you will be riding on the Nine Arches Bridge. Train ride is interesting specially for the kids. Take precaution but it's very interesting to ride by sitting on the steps at the doors. You see people from all walks of life on this train, and odd snack sellers selling delicious deviled prawns on the train. Several small vegetable gardens on the side of the railway, and several rail crossings. In the station you get onboard, be sure to check out the tablet exchange between the Train driver and the Station employee. This is the "permission" note for the train to proceed to the next station (as this is single line track). After viewing the Demodara loop, you can probably walk along the Railway back towards Ella and reach Nine Arches Bridge. We want to Nine Arches Bridge by Vehicles so I don't know how easy or difficult the walk along the railway is towards Nine Arches. See my review of Nine Arches Bridge separately. Tip: If planning to see both Demodara Loop and go to Nine Arches, I recommend following, - Use Badulla bound "Podi Menike" train to go to Demodara (reaches Demodara at around 4+pm). - See the Demodara Loop, and find your way to Nine Archers (either walk or via vehicles). - You can then see next Badulla bound train "Udarata Menike" at Nine Arches at around 5:30pm.

From ella we took a ticket to demodara railway station, which was the next stop further into hill country. The ticket was just LKR 10 each. The ride was about 15minutes. Can see alot of greenery while travelling. If you are taking this ride you will go through two tunnels, one is the popular 9arch bridge tunnel as well and on top of the nine arch bridge. Its an experience. We got off the demodara station and then went to the viewing point to see the demodara loop. Same train goes under the station. Details about the loop are displayed at the station. After viewing the train going through the loop go read the details about the loop in the station. Workers at the station were so helpful as well. The Demodara Loop is basically a Railway construction that circumnavigates a hillock in an attempt to negotiate a substantial elevation difference  on the upcountry railway line in the village of Demodara. This is one of the two main attractions on this line - the other being the equally famous Nine Arch bridge located between the stations of Ella and Demodara some 2.5 kilometres away. What sets this apart from many other loops present on the upcountry line is perhaps the unique way it has been constructed; after passing Demodara station the  track  circles a hillock and proceeds to to travel past a tunnel that is bored right underneath the Demodara Station! If one times his/her visit properly, one can easily observe this  phenomenon from the front compound of the station. If one happens to travel on the train from Badulla toward Colombo in the night mail train, he/she will be able to observe the bright light of the station a hundred feet above first from a distance and then  arrive at the station minutes after which is quite magical.

The Demodara railway line winds its way and goes directly under the station through the tunnel inside a mountain.If you make your way to the back of the railway station (other side of where the tracks are), there is a look out point, where you can stand directly above the tunnel and see the train looping in order to arrive at the station. It is said that the idea of this loop suddenly occurred to the late Mr.D.J.Wimalasurendra who was the greatest Sri Lankan engineer, who masterminded the railway line, when he observed the Kangany who was supervising the workers, undo his 'talappa' (head gear) and re-tie it round his head in a circular motion! Walking along the railway lines in these area is not considered abnormal nor that you have a death wish, as trains come rarely and the laid back staff at the station would happily encourage you to do so giving the approximate time of the train's arrival! They may even show you the 150 year old equipment and explain its functions inside the Railway Master's Office!
